{{Infobox opera | name = {{lang|de|Dantons Tod}} | composer = [[Gottfried von Einem]] | image = Bundesarchiv Bild 183-R72176, Staatsoper Hamburg, "Dantons Tod".jpg | image_upright = 1.3 | caption = A scene in the first performance in Germany at the [[Hamburg State Opera]] in 1948 | translated_name = ''Dantons Death'' | librettist = {{plainlist| * [[Boris Blacher]] * von Einem }} | language = German | based_on = {{based on|''[[Danton's Death]]''|[[Georg Büchner]]}} | premiere_date = {{Start date|1947|08|06|df=y}} | premiere_location = [[Salzburg Festival]] }} '''''{{Lang|de|Dantons Tod}}''''' (German for ''Danton's Death'') is an [[opera]] by [[Gottfried von Einem]] to a [[libretto]] by [[Boris Blacher]] and Gottfried von Einem after [[Georg Büchner]]'s 1835 [[Danton's Death|play of the same name]]. Its first performance took place in Salzburg on 6 August 1947. It was revised in 1955. The successful premiere of Gottfried von Einem's opera ''{{Lang|de|Dantons Tod}}'' at the 1947 [[Salzburg Festival]] and its quick staging by European houses were due to more than the strong drama of Einem's score. This was a first step toward the rehabilitation of German musicians after [[World War II]]; an opera by a young Austrian composer who had not collaborated in the former regime's cultural policies. ''{{Lang|de|Dantons Tod}}'' dramatizes legalized governmental terror, a plague which the world at the time realized had not been eradicated with the end of the war. ==Roles== {| class="wikitable" !Role ![[Voice type]] !Premiere cast 6 August 1947{{cite web | url = http://www.amadeusonline.eu/almanacco.php?Start=0&Giorno=6&Mese=08&Anno=1947&Giornata=&Testo=&Parola=Stringa | title = Almannaco 6 August 1947 | publisher = AmadeusOnline | language = Italian | accessdate = 12 September 2010 }}
[[Conducting|Conductor]]: [[Ferenc Fricsay]] |- |[[Georges Danton]] || [[baritone]] || [[Paul Schöffler]] |- |[[Camille Desmoulins]] || [[tenor]] || [[Julius Patzak]] |- |Lucile || [[soprano]] || [[Maria Cebotari]] |- |[[Marie-Jean Hérault de Séchelles|Hérault de Séchelles]] || tenor || [[Peter Klein (tenor)|Peter Klein]] |- |[[Maximilien Robespierre|Robespierre]] || tenor || [[Josef Witt]] |- |[[Louis Antoine de Saint-Just|Saint-Just]] || [[bass (voice type)|bass]] || [[Ludwig Weber]] |- |Simon || bass || Georg Hann |- |Julie || [[mezzo-soprano]] || Gisela Thury |- |Hermann || bass || Herbert Alsen |- |Simon's wife || [[contralto]] || Rosette Anday |- |Young man || tenor || Erwin Nowaro |- |Two executioners || tenor, bass || William Wernigk, Wilhelm Felden |- |Woman || soprano || Trude Ballasch |- |colspan="3" | Chorus ([[SATB]]) |} ==Synopsis== ''Dantons Tod'' was adapted from Georg Büchner's play by von Einem and his teacher, composer Boris Blacher. The [[protagonist]] is Georges Danton, a leader in the French government during the [[French Revolution|Revolution]]. When he turned against [[Robespierre]]'s tactics—including terror—he was [[guillotine]]d in April 1794. The opera's first act establishes Danton's confrontation with Robespierre. In the first scene Danton and Camille Desmoulins express their desire for an end of the daily executions to a group of their friends playing cards. Scene two introduces the volatile crowd. Robespierre enters and in an [[aria]] sways the crowd and promises more [[Capital punishment|executions]]. Danton confronts him. After Danton leaves, Robespierre and his colleague Saint-Just decide that he and Camille must be killed. In the last scene of the act Danton announces to Camille and his wife Lucile that he is to be arrested, but he refuses to flee. Act 2 depicts Danton's trial and death. Two scenes before the [[Revolutionary Tribunal]] are separated by one with Danton and Camille in prison. Lucile comes to see Camille; she has lost her reason. In the trial scenes the crowd swings between demanding Danton's death and falling under the spell of his eloquent oratory. At the end, in the [[Place de la Révolution]], the condemned prisoners sing "[[La Marseillaise]]" in counterpoint to the crowd dancing the [[Carmagnole]]. Danton and Camille are guillotined. After the crowd disperses, Lucile enters and sits on the steps of the guillotine. She cries ''Es lebe der Konig'' (Long live the king) and is arrested as the curtain falls. Von Einem revised the score slightly after the premier, replacing an orchestral [[Prelude (music)|prelude]] with the [[Chord (music)|chords]] that now open the opera, cutting an orchestral passage after Danton's death, and revising the final scene with Lucile. These changes make for a more dramatic beginning and ending and add to a score that deserves more frequent revivals than it has seen to date. == Recordings == *[[Paul Schöffler]] as Danton, [[Julius Patzak]] as Desmoulins and [[Maria Cebotari]] as Lucile. This is a live recording taken from the premiere in Salzburg on August 6, 1947 with the [[Vienna Philharmonic]] and [[Vienna State Opera]] Chorus conducted by [[Ferenc Fricsay]]. A recording is available on Allegro Corporation's Opera D'Oro label.[http://www.allegro-music.com/online_catalog.asp?sku_tag=OPD31316 ''Dantons Tod'' page on Allegro website] *[[Theo Adam]], Werner Hollweg, Horst Hiestermann, [[Krisztina Laki]], ORF Chor & Orchester, [[Lothar Zagrosek]] Orfeo 1983 == References == {{Reflist}} {{Gottfried von Einem}} {{Portal bar|Opera}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1947 operas]] [[Category:Death in music]] [[Category:German-language operas]] [[Category:Operas]] [[Category:Operas set in the French Revolution]] [[Category:Operas based on real people]] [[Category:Operas set in France]] [[Category:Operas set in the 18th century]] [[Category:Operas by Gottfried von Einem]] [[Category:Works about Georges Danton]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Georges Danton]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Maximilien Robespierre]]

Sommers }} | editor = {{Plainlist| *Joe Leonard *Zack Arnold *Raúl Dávalos *Natalie A. Boschan *Matt Barber }} | runtime = 42 minutes | company = {{Plainlist| * [[Imagine Entertainment|Imagine Television]] * Lee Daniels Entertainment * Danny Strong Productions * Little Chicken Inc. * [[20th Century Fox Television]] }} | distributor = [[20th Television]] | channel = [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2015|1|7}} | last_aired = {{End date|present}} | related = | website = http://www.fox.com/empire/ }} '''''Empire''''' is an American [[Musical film|musical]] [[Drama (film and television)|drama]] [[Television show|television series]] created by [[Lee Daniels]] and [[Danny Strong]] which debuted on January 7, 2015 on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]. Although it is filmed in [[Chicago]],{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3228904/locations?ref_=tt_ql_dt_6|title=Empire|date=January 7, 2015|publisher=|accessdate=July 27, 2016|via=IMDb}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/feb/06/empire-economy-fox-drama-chicago|title='The Empire economy': how the hit Fox show is making Chicago swing|first=Britt|last=Julious|date=February 6, 2015|publisher=|accessdate=July 27, 2016}} the show is set in [[New York City|New York]]. It centers on a fictional [[hip hop music]] and [[entertainment]] company, Empire Entertainment, and the drama among the members of the founders' family as they fight for control of it. A hip-hop mogul must choose a successor among his three sons who are battling for control over his multimillion-dollar company, while his wife schemes to reclaim what is hers. The pilot was shown to be a success, garnering praise for [[Taraji P. Henson]]'s portrayal of Cookie Lyon and the premiere receiving nearly 10 million viewers and the season finale with 17 million viewers. On January 11, 2017, Fox renewed the series for a [[Empire (season 4)|fourth season]], consisting of eighteen episodes.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/01/empire-renewed-season-4-fox-tca-1201883228/|title=‘Empire’ Renewed For Season 4 By Fox|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Nellie|last=Andreeva|date=January 11, 2017|accessdate=January 11, 2017}} The season premiered on September 27, 2017, and crossed over with another Fox series co-created by Daniels, ''[[Star (TV series)|Star]]''.{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2017/07/12/empire-star-crossover-cookie-carlotta-video/|title=Empire/Star Crossover Confirmed — It's Cookie vs. Carlotta (Watch Teaser)|last=Ausiello|first=Michael|publisher=TVLine|date=July 12, 2017|accessdate=July 12, 2017}} On May 2, 2018, Fox renewed the series for a [[Empire (season 5)|fifth season]] with Brett Mahoney taking over as showrunner from [[Ilene Chaiken]].{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/05/empire-renewed-season-5-fox-brett-mahoney-showrunner-1202381308/|title=‘Empire’ Renewed For Season 5 By Fox With Brett Mahoney As Showrunner|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=May 2, 2018|accessdate=May 3, 2018}} The season premiered on September 26, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/06/fox-fall-premiere-dates-2018-empire-9-1-1-lethal-weapon-last-man-standing-nfl-1202418890/|title=Fox Sets Fall Premiere Dates: 'Empire', '9-1-1', Recast 'Lethal Weapon' & More|last=Pedersen|first=Erik|work=Deadline Hollywood|date=June 28, 2018|accessdate=June 28, 2018}} ==Premise== [[Lucious Lyon]] ([[Terrence Howard]]) is a hip hop mogul, former drug dealer, and CEO of Empire Entertainment. Informed of his own imminent early death from a certain medical condition, Lucious is forced to choose from amongst his progeny, a successor who will control his dynasty after his demise. He begins working to groom one of his three sons to take over the family business – Empire CFO [[Andre Lyon (Empire)|Andre]] ([[Trai Byers]]), R&B singer-songwriter [[Jamal Lyon|Jamal]] ([[Jussie Smollett]]), and rapper [[Hakeem Lyon|Hakeem]] ([[Bryshere Y. Gray]]) – In the process, Lucious pits them against each other.{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/television/Terrence-Howard-Rules-Hip-Hop-Family-Fox-Empire-Trailer-64018.html|title=Terrence Howard Rules Hip Hop And Family In Fox's Empire Trailer|work=cinemablend.com|last=West|first=Kelly|date=July 9, 2014|accessdate=July 9, 2015}} Lucious' ex-wife [[Cookie Lyon]] ([[Taraji P. Henson]]) is released from prison after serving a 17-year sentence, and also pulls for control of both the company and of her sons. The second season primarily focuses on the competition between Lyon Dynasty, formed and headed by Cookie and Empire. ==Cast and characters== {{Main|List of Empire characters}} * [[Terrence Howard]] as [[Lucious Lyon|Dwight Walker / Lucious Lyon]] : A former drug dealer turned hip-hop mogul and the founder and long-time CEO of Empire Entertainment, his life begins to cave in around him after his past sins come back to haunt him when he is diagnosed with [[Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis|ALS]] and later on found out to lose his memory during an assassination attempt (season 3) but regains it (season 4) * [[Taraji P. Henson]] as [[Cookie Lyon|Loretha Holloway / Cookie Lyon]] : Lucious' outspoken wife and mother of his three sons. She serves a 17-year stretch in prison for [[drug dealing]] and sees herself as the sacrificial lamb for Empire Entertainment, which she built with Lucious, but then took the fall for him while running the very drugs that financed Lucious' early career. Upon her return from prison, she is determined to bring the Lyon family back together and reclaim her share of Empire Entertainment.{{cite web |title=Everything You Need to Know About 'Empire,' TV's Most Talked-About New Show!|url=http://www.etonline.com/tv/157052_everything_you_need_to_know_about_empire_tv_s_most_talked_about_new_show/ |first=Meredith B. |last=Kile |date=January 28, 2015 |publisher=[[Entertainment Tonight|ET Online]] |accessdate=March 25, 2015 }} In the second season, Cookie leaves the Empire group and starts her own record label, Lyon Dynasty. After allowing Empire Entertainment to acquire Lyon Dynasty, she returns to Empire as co-CEO and Head of [[A&R]]. Cookie's lovers were Malcolm Deveaux (season 1), Laz Delgado (season 2) and Angelo DuBois (season 3). * [[Bryshere Y. Gray]] as [[Hakeem Lyon]] : Lucious' fame-obsessed youngest son and his favorite child, who is a hip hop star on the rise.{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2014/03/ryan-mcpartlin-joins-nbc-pilot-salvation-bryshere-y-gray-cast-in-foxs-empire-694998/ |title=Ryan McPartlin Joins NBC Pilot 'Salvation'; Bryshere Y. Gray Cast In Fox's 'Empire' |date=March 6, 2014 |accessdate=January 2, 2015 |first=Nellie|last=Andreeva |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]}} Initially combative towards his mother Cookie, Hakeem starts to become friendlier towards her, and has a great relationship with his older brother Jamal. He has had romantic relationships with Tiana, Camilla, Anika, Valentina, and Laura. * [[Jussie Smollett]] as [[Jamal Lyon]] : The middle son of the Lyon family, he is a talented gay singer-songwriter who despises the corporate aspect of the music industry. Jamal is estranged from his father, who considers him the [[black sheep]] of the family. Jamal is Cookie's favorite and has a strong relationship with his brother Hakeem. Lucious appoints Jamal as his successor at the end of the first season, and later as interim CEO when Lucious is arrested. Jamal later relinquishes control of Empire back to Lucious. After being accidentally shot by Freda Gatz in Season 2, Jamal begins to present symptoms of PTSD and a reliance on painkillers. His addiction ultimately leads to a visit to rehab. * [[Trai Byers]] as [[Andre Lyon (Empire)|Andre Lyon]] : The eldest son of the Lyon family and [[CFO]] of Empire Entertainment. He is [[Wharton School of Business|Wharton]] educated, power hungry, and suffers from [[bipolar disorder]]. He is married to his college sweetheart, Rhonda. He plans to run Empire, but is in a battle for the head chair with his younger brothers. In the second season, Andre initially helps Cookie and Hakeem set up Lyon Dynasty, but returns to Empire. Lucious later promotes Andre to President of Gutter Life Records, a sub-division of Empire Entertainment consisting of mainly urban rappers, such as Freda Gatz. In Season 3, 4 & 5, he loses his wife and becomes involved with Nessa, Charlotte, Pamela and Teri. * [[Grace Gealey|Grace Byers]] as Anika Calhoun (seasons 1–4) : Initially the ambitious head of Empire Entertainment's [[A&R]] department, she becomes engaged to Lucious though they will eventually separate. After leaving Empire, Anika begins to sleep with Hakeem and becomes pregnant. Fearful of Rhonda's pregnancy, as Rhonda's unborn child has claim to being the heir of Empire, Anika pushes Rhonda down a set of stairs, leading to the death of Rhonda's unborn child. Cookie and Anika share an extreme dislike for one another, with Cookie referring to Anika by the derisive nickname "[[Laverne & Shirley|Boo Boo Kitty]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/03/02/empire-star-taraji-p-henson-her-signature-line-you-don%E2%80%99t-want-be-called-boo-boo|title=Empire star Taraji P. Henson on her signature line: 'You don't want to be called Boo Boo Kitty' | last=Stack |first=Tim | date=March 2, 2015 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |accessdate=March 5, 2015}} * [[Malik Yoba]] as Vernon Turner (season 1) : Lucious's longtime friend and business partner, and chairman of Empire Entertainment. In the season one finale, Vernon is struck and killed by Rhonda, when he attacks Andre, and both end up hiding the body.{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2014/03/malik-yoba-joins-fox-drama-pilot-empire-695848/ |title=Malik Yoba Joins Fox Drama Pilot 'Empire' |date=March 7, 2014 |first=Nellie |last=Andreeva |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=January 2, 2015}} * [[Kaitlin Doubleday]] as Rhonda Lyon (seasons 1–2; recurring in season 3; guest in season 4){{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2014/03/kaitlin-doubleday-joins-fox-drama-pilot-empire-regina-hall-in-fxs-married-697294/ |title=Kaitlin Doubleday Joins Fox Drama Pilot 'Empire'; Regina Hall In FX's 'Married' |date=March 11, 2014 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=January 2, 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://theurbandaily.com/2014/10/28/chris-powell-empire-tv-show/|title=Comedian CP (Chris Powell) Lands Role In Lee Daniels' "Empire" [EXCLUSIVE VIDEO] |work=theurbandaily.com|date=October 28, 2014|accessdate=February 11, 2015}} : Andre's wife is a "[[ride-or-die chick]]" who is extremely fierce and loyal, and sticks by Andre's side as he tries to gain control of Empire. In the first-season finale she finds out that she is pregnant, but Anika pushes her down the stairs in the second season fall finale, and the baby dies in the second-season spring premiere. After her recovery, Rhonda begins to work for Empire's fashion label, "Antony and Cleopatra", initially run by Camilla Marks-Whiteman. After Camilla's suicide, Rhonda is appointed Creative Director of Antony and Cleopatra. In the third-season premiere, she attacks Anika due to finding out Anika had pushed her down the stairs earlier in the season, causing her to lose her unborn son. As a result, she falls off the building she and Anika were fighting on, lands on a car, and dies. She makes numerous appearances to Andre as a ghost during his hallucinations in the third season. * [[Ta'Rhonda Jones]] as Porsha Taylor (season 2–present; recurring in season 1) : Cookie's executive assistant. * [[Gabourey Sidibe]] as Rebecca "Becky" Williams (season 2–present; recurring in season 1) : Executive assistant to Lucious at Empire Entertainment. After Jamal's promotion to Vice Chairman, Jamal promotes Becky to A&R at Empire and its sub-label, Gutter Life Records. In Season 4, she had taken Anika's position as Head of A&R requested by Cookie.{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2014/03/gabourey-sidibe-joins-fox-drama-pilot-empire-andrew-lees-in-tbs-your-family-or-mine-696557/ |title=Gabourey Sidibe & 2 More Join Fox Pilot 'Empire'; Andrew Lees In TBS' 'Your Family Or Mine' |date=March 10, 2014 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=January 2, 2015}} * [[Serayah (actress)|Serayah]] as Tiana Brown—Lyon (season 2–present; recurring in season 1) : An artist at Empire Entertainment who becomes Hakeem's girlfriend for some time.{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2015/08/26/empire-serayah-series-regular-season-2/|title=Empire Promotes Serayah for Season 2|accessdate=September 10, 2015|first=Kimberly|last=Roots|date=August 26, 2015|work=[[TVLine]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]}} In season two, she leaves Empire for Lyon Dynasty. She also starts to get jealous of the relationship Hakeem has with Laura. In Season 3, she and Hakeem rekindle their relationship. At the beginning of Season 4 she remains happy being with Hakeem and looks after his daughter Bella whilst Anika is in jail. Halfway through the season she gets manipulated by Eddie Barker and turns down a proposal made by Hakeem. She continues to be manipulated by Eddie and becomes Empire's number one artist. After Hakeem tries to warn her about Eddie she breaks up with him again, but they quickly get back together after Tiana reveals to Hakeem that she's pregnant. * Bre-Z as Freda Gathers/"Freda Gatz" (season 3; recurring in season 2) : A female rapper, who becomes a surrogate daughter to Lucious after the murder of her father, Frank Gathers. Lucious later sets up Freda to become Hakeem's rival. * [[Morocco Omari]] as Tariq Cousins (season 3; recurring in season 2) : An [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] Agent, who is also Lucious' half-brother.{{cite web|last=Slezak |first=Michael |url=http://tvline.com/2016/02/05/empire-season-2-cast-morocco-omari-fbi-agent/ |title=‘Empire’ Season 2 Casts Morocco Omari as FBI Agent |website=TVLine.com |date=2016-02-05 |accessdate=2017-01-26}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://2paragraphs.com/2016/09/who-is-lucious-half-brother-tariq-on-empire/amp/ |title=Who Is Lucious’ Half-Brother Tariq on ‘Empire’? – |website=2paragraphs.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-26}} * [[Xzibit]] as Leslie 'Shyne' Johnson (season 3–4; guest in season 2) : A former rival of [[Lucious Lyon]], described as "100 percent wolf and 100 percent gangsta". * [[Andre Royo]] as Thurston ‘Thirsty’ Rawlings, (season 4–present; seasons 2−3 recurring) : Lucious’ lawyer. * [[Rumer Willis]] as Tory Ash, (season 4; season 3 guest) :A singer who fell off as an addict. * Terrell Carter as Warren Hall, (season 4) :An attorney, Diana Dubois’ nephew, Angelo’s cousin and Jamal’s ex. * [[Nicole Ari Parker]] as Giselle Sims-Barker, (season 5–present; season 4 recurring) : Eddie Barker’s trophy ex-wife. * [[Chet Hanks]] as Blake Sterling, (season 5–present; season 4 recurring) :A rapper and Hakeem’s friend. * [[Rhyon Nicole Brown]] as Maya (season 5-present; season 4 recurring) :The daughter of Cookie’s fellow inmate Poundcake. * A.Z. Kelsey as Jeff Kingsley (season 5-present) :Hotshot, Silicon Valley genius turned interim leader of Empire Entertainment. He’s Ivy League educated with an edge and a dark secret. He might be Lucious' son ==Episodes== {{main|List of Empire episodes}} {{:List of Empire episodes}} ==Production== [[File:"VOICE AWARDS-2015" (21409573660).jpg|thumb|left|Joshua Allen and Attica Locke, writers and producers of the show Empire, stand with their 2015 Voice Award. They are joined by Sonay Washington Hoffman from Writers Guild of America, West.]] Howard, Henson and Sidibe filmed the [[pilot episode]] in [[Chicago]] in March 2014.{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2014-05-07/entertainment/chi-lee-daniels-empire-chicago-fox-20140507_1_lee-daniels-francie-calfo-the-butler|title=Lee Daniels' 'Empire' picked up by Fox, will 'likely' film in Chicago|accessdate=May 12, 2014|date=May 7, 2014|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|last=Gomez|first=Luis}} On May 6, 2014, [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] picked up ''Empire'' as a series order for its [[2014–15 United States network television schedule|2014–15 television schedule]].{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2014/05/06/foxs-hip-hop-drama-empire-gets-series-order/|title=Lee Daniels hip-hop drama 'Empire' gets Fox series order|accessdate=May 12, 2014|date=May 6, 2014|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|last=Hibberd|first= James}}{{cite |accessdate=May 12, 2014|date=May 6, 2014|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|last=Braxton|first=Greg}} On May 12, 2014, Fox announced that ''Empire'' would air as a midseason replacement, rather than as a part of the fall schedule.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/05/12/fox-2014-15-schedule-announced-gotham-mondays-bones-shifts-to-thursday-brooklyn-nine-nine-joins-sunday/262992/|title=Fox 2014–15 Schedule Announced: 'Gotham' & 'Sleepy Hollow' Monday, 'Bones' Shifts to Thursday & 'Brooklyn Nine-Nine' Joins Sunday With 'Mulaney' + 'Glee' Held for Midseason|publisher=Tribune Digital Ventures|accessdate=October 28, 2014|date=May 12, 2014|work=TV by the Numbers|last=Kondolojy|first= Amanda}}{{cite web|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|title=Fox 2014 Schedule: 'Brooklyn Nine-Nine' & 'Mulaney' Join Sunday Animated Block, 'Glee' Held For Midseason|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/05/fox-fall-schedule-2014-upfronts-new-shows/|accessdate=May 12, 2014|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=May 12, 2014}} On November 19, 2014, it was confirmed that the [[Pilot (Empire)|pilot episode]] would premiere on January 7, 2015, following the [[American Idol (season 14)|season 14]] premiere of ''[[American Idol]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/foxs-empire-nabs-post-american-749190|title=Fox's 'Empire' Nabs Post-'American Idol' Slot: It's not immediately clear what the new Wednesday means for current occupant 'Red Band Society'|accessdate=November 20, 2014|date=November 19, 2014|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|last=O'Connell|first= Michael}} The [[executive producer]]s are [[Brian Grazer]], [[Danny Strong]] and Francie Calfo. The show is written by Strong while [[Lee Daniels]], who has been nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Director]], made his television directorial debut with the show.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/lee-daniels-foxs-empire-i-701855|title=Lee Daniels on Fox's 'Empire': 'I Wanted to Make a Black 'Dynasty' ' (Q&A)|accessdate=December 14, 2014|date=May 6, 2014|last=Wilson|first=Stacey|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=Prometheus Global Media}} According to Strong, the show is based in part on [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[King Lear]]'', and James Goldman's ''[[The Lion in Winter]]''; Daniels also acknowledged a strong influence from the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] prime-time [[soap opera]] ''[[Dynasty (1981 TV series)|Dynasty]]''. Because he felt his own musical tastes and desires would be a little too dated for the show, Daniels consulted with people he thought could give him a little more insight, his children. At the urging of his son and daughter, Daniels contacted super producer [[Timbaland|Timothy "Timbaland" Mosley]], known for scoring hits with some of pop's biggest artists including [[Missy Elliott]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Brandy Norwood|Brandy]], [[Destiny's Child]], [[Justin Timberlake]], [[Jay-Z]], [[Nelly Furtado]], [[Ginuwine]] and [[Aaliyah]].{{cite web|url=http://www.songfacts.com/category-songs_produced_by_timbaland.php|title=SONGS PRODUCED BY TIMBALAND|publisher=Songfacts.com|accessdate=January 28, 2015}} As executive music Producer, Timbaland, co-songwriter/producer [[Jim Beanz]], and a team of other musical collaborators took their cues from the writing team, which gave them an idea of where the plot is headed, and craft songs to fit those themes. However, the musical aspect of the series is very reality based, unlike Fox's last musical series, ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'', performances come with the organic development of the characters as artists, much like the performances featured in the ABC prime-time country musical drama ''[[Nashville (2012 TV series)|Nashville]]''.{{cite web|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2015/01/07/empire-fox-lee-daniels/|title='Empire': Inside Fox's ambitious, groundbreaking musical soap|first=Tim|last=Stack|date=January 7, 2015|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|accessdate=January 7, 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://alistarrecords.com/track/731526/what-the-dj-spins-from-empire?feature_id=157084&trackship_id=833644 |title=What the DJ Spins (Empire) |publisher=Alistar Records |access-date=June 24, 2015}} Any licensed songs and composer Fil Eisler's score are added after the episodes are filmed. The pilot itself consists of 12 songs.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/tv/features/timbaland-gives-lee-daniels-empire-hip-hop-cred-1201393126/|title=Timbaland Gives Lee Daniels' 'Empire' Hip-Hop Cred|first=Melinda|last=Newman|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|date=January 6, 2015|accessdate=January 7, 2015}} [[Columbia Records]] releases weekly soundtracks of ''Empire'' on the [[iTunes Store]], the same strategy used with ''Glee''.{{Cite web |url=http://www.inquisitr.com/1860247/empire-tv-show-on-fox-empire-soundtrack-music-soars-on-itunes-ratings-break-records/ |title=‘EMPIRE’ TV SHOW ON FOX: ‘EMPIRE’ SOUNDTRACK MUSIC SOARS ON ITUNES, RATINGS BREAK RECORDS |last=Mooney |first=Paula |date=February 20, 2015|accessdate=March 24, 2017}} In May 2015, Fox announced that [[Ne-Yo]] and [[J.R. Rotem]] would write music for the show's second season, joining Timbaland. Timbaland left ''Empire'' after season 2, and were replaced for season 3 by [[Rodney "Darkchild" Jerkins]] and [[Esther Dean]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fuse.tv/2016/09/empire-timbaland-exit-ester-dean-rodney-jerkins-darkchild|title='EMPIRE' LOSES TIMBALAND, SIGNS ESTER DEAN & RODNEY 'DARKCHILD' JERKINS |first=Melinda|last=Newman|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|date=September 15, 2016|accessdate=March 24, 2017}} On September 8, 2015, Scott Hoying and Mitch Grassi from [[Pentatonix]] arranged a medley of songs from the first season of Empire and posted it on their shared YouTube comedy/music channel, [[Superfruit (web show)|Superfruit]]. The video was sponsored by the Fox Broadcasting Company. ====Soundtracks==== {{main|Empire discography}} [[Columbia Records]] released the official [[soundtrack]] of ''Empire''’s first season on March 10, 2015.{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/original-soundtrack-from-season/id966019045 |title=Original Soundtrack from Season 1 of Empire by Empire Cast |work=[[iTunes Store]] |publisher=[[Apple Inc.|Apple]] |accessdate=March 18, 2015}} The soundtrack consists of 11 songs and the deluxe version consists of 18 songs, all performed on the show. As of October 2015, the album has sold 439,000 total copies in the United States.{{cite web |url=http://www.nielsen.com/us/en/insights/news/2015/a-sprawling-empire-how-foxs-hit-tv-show-affects-music.html |title=A SPRAWLING EMPIRE: HOW FOX'S HIT TV SHOW AFFECTS MUSIC |website=nielsen |date=September 23, 2015 |accessdate=October 10, 2015}} Additional releases have followed for subsequent seasons. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |- ! received positive reviews from critics. The praise has gone towards the cast, particularly Howard and Henson.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-cookie-lucious-how-taraji-p-henson-and-terrence-howard-built-an-empire-20150319-story.html |title=Cookie & Lucious: How Taraji P. Henson and Terrence Howard Built an 'Empire' |date=March 19, 2015 |work=latimes.com}} On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the first season has a rating of 80%, based on 48 reviews, with an average rating of 7.1/10.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/empire/s01/|title=Empire: Season 1|date=January 7, 2015|work=rottentomatoes.com}} The site's critical consensus reads, "Though heavy on melodrama, ''Empire'' elevates the nighttime soap with its top-notch cast, musical entertainment, and engrossing plots."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/empire/s01/|title=Empire: Season 1|date=January 29, 2015|publisher=|accessdate=January 8, 2015}} On [[Metacritic]] the show has a score of 72 out of 100, based on 39 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/tv/empire-2015|title=Empire (2015)|work=Metacritic|accessdate=January 29, 2015}} For the second season, it built up more acclaim from critics, praising the performances of Henson and Howard, the character development, plot development, and the show's self-awareness for being a soap opera. On Rotten Tomatoes, the second season has a 95% "Certified Fresh" with an average rating of 7.8/10 from critics and a score of 77 from Metacritic, indicating "generally positive reviews". [[David Wiegand]] wrote in the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'': "Almost nothing about ''Empire'', created by Lee Daniels (''[[The Butler]]''), feels original, but after a few minutes, you will stop caring".{{cite news |url=http://seattletimes.com/html/television/2025339152_empirefoxxml.html|title='Empire' rocks on Fox, clichés and all|accessdate=December 30, 2014|date=December 29, 2014|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |via=[[The Seattle Times]] |last=Wiegand |first=Dave}} [[50 Cent]] stated via [[Twitter]] that he feels that ''Empire'' is being marketed by FOX in a way that resembles the marketing for the 2014 [[Starz (TV channel)|Starz]] series that he produces called ''[[Power (TV series)|Power]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2036414/50-cent-empire-power-fox-beef/|title=50 Cent's Latest Beef Is With A New Fox TV Show|accessdate=December 30, 2014|date=December 29, 2014|work=[[MTV News]]|publisher=Viacom Media Networks|last=Fleischer|first=Adam}} [[Michael Logan (journalist)|Michael Logan]] of ''[[TV Guide]]'' described ''Empire'' as a "sudsy retooling of ''[[King Lear]]'' with hip hop as the backdrop and praised Henson for her portrayal of the character Cookie.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/empire-fox-lee-daniels-1091355.aspx|title=Lee Daniels Builds a Soapy New Hip-Hop Empire for Fox|date=December 31, 2014|first=Michael|last=Logan|authorlink=Michael Logan (journalist)|accessdate=January 3, 2015|work=[[TV Guide]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]}} The show's premiere ranked as Fox's highest-rated debut in three years. Viewership has increased continuously; ''Empire'' is the first primetime broadcast series in at least 23 years to have its viewership increase week to week for its first five episodes.{{cite web|last1=Bibel|first1=Sara|title=FOX's 'Empire' Is The Only Primetime Broadcast Series To Grow In Viewers in Each of its First 5 Telecasts in at Least 23 Years|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2015/02/06/foxs-empire-is-the-only-primetime-broadcast-series-to-grow-in-viewers-in-each-of-its-first-5-telecasts-in-at-least-23-years/360518/|accessdate=February 6, 2015|work=TV by the Numbers|publisher=Tribune Digital Ventures|date=February 6, 2015}} The show continues to increase its viewership with further episodes.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/style-blog/wp/2015/02/26/this-is-tv-history-empire-continues-to-rise-in-the-ratings-and-nothing-ever-rises-in-the-ratings/|title=This is TV history: 'Empire' keeps rising in the ratings — and nothing EVER rises in the ratings|last=Yahr|first=Emily|work=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=Nash Holdings LLC|date=February 26, 2015|accessdate=February 26, 2015}} Episodes of the show have also been heavily watched on Video on Demand and other streaming services.{{cite news|last1=Steel|first1=Emily|title='Empire' May Provide Fox the Big Hit It Needs|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/28/business/media/empire-may-provide-fox-the-big-hit-it-needs.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&module=mini-moth®ion=top-stories-below&WT.nav=top-stories-below|accessdate=January 28, 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=January 28, 2015}} As of its first season finale, ''Empire'' has now surpassed ''[[The Big Bang Theory]]'' as the highest rated scripted program in the 2014–2015 television season. The first season finale is also the highest rated debut season finale since May 2005, when ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]'' ended its first season. ''Empire's'' season one finale grew 82 percent from its series premiere, making it the show that has grown the most over the course of its first season since ''[[Men in Trees]]'' during the 2006–2007 season.{{cite web|last1=Bibel|first1=Sara|title=TV Ratings Wednesday: Updated -'Empire' Finale Soars to Huge Series High, 'Arrow', 'Supernatural' & 'CSI: Cyber' Down|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2015/03/19/tv-ratings-wednesday-empire-finale-soars-to-huge-series-high-arrow-supernatural-csi-cyber-down/376814/|accessdate=February 6, 2015|work=TV by the Numbers|publisher=Tribune Digital Ventures|date=March 19, 2015}} ==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="font-size\ |- ! revision.text:
'''Empty books''' or '''blank books''' are [[Novelty item|novelty]] [[book]]s whose title indicates that they treat some serious subject, but whose pages have been [[Intentionally blank page|left intentionally blank]]. A number of such titles have been published as attempts at satire or polemic, to some commercial success.
The joke is that "nothing" is the answer to whatever the title of the book asserts. In 2017, ''[[The Guardian]]'' commented that the trend of publishing political empty books had led to "the noble art of political [[parody]] [descending] into a one-joke turn that avoids words".<ref name="KeanSatire" />
==List of empty books== {{incomplete list|date=March 2018}} This list includes, in order of publication, empty books that have been published with an [[ISBN]] and have received coverage in reliable sources unrelated to the author. The books may have [[book design]] features such as [[front matter]], a table of contents, page numbers, etc., as long as the pages are otherwise blank. *{{cite book|authorlink=Shed Simove|last1=Simove|first1=Sheridan|title=What Every Man Thinks About Apart from Sex.|date=2011|publisher=[[Summersdale]]|isbn=978-1849531986}} Popular among British university students who used it as a notebook.<ref>{{cite news|title=What Every Man Thinks About Apart From Sex: book of blank pages become surprise bestseller|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/booknews/8358538/What-Every-Man-Thinks-About-Apart-From-Sex-book-of-blank-pages-become-surprise-bestseller.html|accessdate=11 March 2018|work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|date=3 March 2011}}</ref> *{{cite book|last1=Moncrief|first1=Jimmy|title=Everything Obama Knows About The Economy|date=2011|publisher=Self-published|isbn=0980074231}}<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pappas|first1=Alex |title=This Guy Published A Book Of 200 Blank Pages: 'Everything Obama Knows About The Economy'|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/this-guy-published-a-book-of-200-blank-pages-everything-obama-knows-about-the-economy-2011-12 |accessdate=11 March 2018|work=[[Business Insider]]|date=December 20, 2011}}</ref> *{{cite book|last1=Simove|first1=Shed|title=Fifty Shades of Gray|date=1 August 2012|publisher=Self-published|isbn=978-0956827845}} 200 blank pages in various shades of the color [[gray]]. Removed from circulation after legal action by the publisher of the novel ''[[Fifty Shades of Grey]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Meet the Man Who Sold Hundreds of Thousands of Books With Blank Pages in Them|url=http://observer.com/2016/04/meet-the-man-who-sold-hundreds-of-thousands-of-books-with-blank-pages-in-them/|accessdate=12 March 2018|work=Observer|date=20 April 2016}}</ref> *{{cite book|last1=Johns|first1=Sassy|title=Why Dogs are Better than Cats|date=2014|publisher=[[CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform]]|isbn=1497370116}} 100 pages. * {{cite book|title=The Wit and Wisdom of Nigel Farage|date=1 June 2014|publisher=[[Ebury Press]]|isbn=978-0091960094}} Angered [[UKIP]] supporters who bought it in the belief that it contained actual pronouncements by [[Nigel Farage]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wheaton|first1=Oliver|title=Ukip supporters want this satirical book about Nigel Farage banned|url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/01/12/ukip-supporters-want-the-satirical-book-about-nigel-farage-that-is-full-of-blank-pages-banned-5019587/|accessdate=11 March 2018|work=[[Metro (website)|Metro]]|date=12 January 2015}}</ref> *{{cite book|last1=Alystiam|first1=Ann|title=Surprising Reasons to Believe Trump Will Be a Great President!|date=25 November 2016|publisher=Self-published|isbn=978-0991068944}} Authored by former Oregon First Lady [[Cylvia Hayes]], under a pseudonym.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hanrahan|first1=Kieran|title=Cylvia Hayes' New Book On Trump Is A Page-Turner|url=https://www.opb.org/news/article/cylvia-hayes-book-donald-trump/|accessdate=11 March 2018|work=OPB News|date=16 December 2016|language=en}}</ref> *{{cite book|last1=King|first1=David|title=Why Trump Deserves Trust, Respect and Admiration|date=30 November 2016|publisher=CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform|isbn=978-1540743220}}<ref>{{cite news|last1=Greene|first1=Leonard|title=New book on reasons to trust Trump made of blank pages|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/new-book-reasons-trust-trump-made-blank-pages-article-1.2961880|accessdate=11 March 2018|work=[[NY Daily News]]|date=1 February 2017|language=en}}</ref> *{{cite book|authorlink=Michael J. Knowles|last1=Knowles|first1=Michael J.|title=[[Reasons To Vote For Democrats]]: A Comprehensive Guide|date=8 February 2017|publisher=CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform|isbn=978-1543024975}} A bestseller on [[Amazon.com]] and promoted on Twitter by [[Donald Trump]].<ref name="KeanSatire">{{cite news|last1=Kean|first1=Danuta|title=Empty satire: the regrettable rise of blank-paged books in the Trump era|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2017/apr/18/empty-satire-the-regrettable-rise-of-blank-paged-books-in-the-trump-era|accessdate=23 February 2018|publisher=The Guardian|date=18 April 2017}}</ref> *{{cite book|last1=Voll|first1=Assaf|title=[[A History of the Palestinian People]]|date=12 June 2017|publisher=CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform|isbn=978-1546831242}} A "bestseller on [[Amazon.com]]" (where it was the 543rd most sold book), until it was removed<ref>{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Empty Book on Palestinian History Becomes Instant Best-seller on Amazon|url=https://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/palestinians/empty-book-on-palestinian-history-is-amazon-best-seller-1.5487473 |accessdate=11 March 2018|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=22 June 2017|language=en}}</ref>

{{about|the poem|the salute|Flag salute}} "'''Flag Salute'''" is a poem written by [[Esther Popel]] about the [[lynching]] of [[George Armwood]] on October 18, 1933 in [[Princess Anne, Maryland]].<ref name=cover>{{cite journal|journal=[[The Crisis]]|date=November 1940|page=Cover|title=''Flag Salute''|url=http://archives.dickinson.edu/node/10310/zoomify|accessdate=27 April 2015|publisher=[[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]]}}</ref><ref name=rice>{{cite book|last1=Rice|first1=Anne P.|title=Witnessing Lynching: American Writers Respond|date=October 9, 2008|publisher=[[Rutgers University Press]]|isbn=978-0813533308|page=282|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xfSdgkSjsHUC&lpg=PA282&dq=esther%20popel%20flag%20salute&pg=PA282#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=27 April 2015}}</ref> It was first published in August 1934 in ''[[The Crisis]]''<ref name=Harlem>{{cite book|last1=West|first1=Sandra L.|title=Encyclopedia of the Harlem Renaissance|publisher=[[Amazon Digital Services|Amazon Digital Services, Inc.]]|page=266|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XP48QWTmjyUC&lpg=PA266&dq=esther%20popel%20flag%20salute&pg=PA266#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=27 April 2015|date=September 1, 2003}}</ref> and later republished in its entirety on the cover of ''The Crisis'' in 1940.<ref name=cover/>
It juxtaposes the murder of Armwood with quotations from the [[Pledge of Allegiance (United States)|Pledge of Allegiance]].<ref name=Bracks>{{cite book|last1=Bracks|first1=Lean'tin L|last2=Smith|first2=Jessie Carney|title=Black Women of the Harlem Renaissance Era|publisher=Bowman and Little Field|page=173|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lyMvBQAAQBAJ&dq=%22Black+Women+of+the+Harlem+renaissance%22&lr=&source=gbs_navlinks_s|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref> The poem reflects that [[lynching]] in the United States had become a "ritual of interracial social control."<ref name=Selim>{{cite book|last1=Selim|first1=Yasser Fouad|title=Who Defines Me: Negotiating Identity in Language and Literature|date=2014|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|location=[[Newcastle upon Tyne]]|isbn=1443859680|page=91|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ac8xBwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA91&dq=esther%20popel%20flag%20salute&pg=PA91#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=27 April 2015}}</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=March 2008}} [[File:XRF-the don hiyala & alifulhu story.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Donhiyala's death from the story ''Donhiyala and Alifulhu''.]] [[File:Hahuraa-ruu1.jpg|thumb|right|Copy of a magical drawing. Hodado. [[Fua Mulaku]].]] '''Maldivian mythology''' or '''Maldivian folklore''' is the body of myths, tales and anecdotes belonging to the oral tradition of [[Maldivians]]. Even though some of the Maldivian myths were already mentioned briefly by British commissioner in Ceylon [[Harry Charles Purvis Bell|HCP Bell]] towards the end of the 19th century,<ref>HCP Bell, ''The Máldive Islands: An account of the Physical Features, History, Inhabitants, Productions and Trade''. Colombo, 1883</ref> their study and publication were carried out only quite recently by Spanish writer and artist [[Xavier Romero-Frias]], at a time when that ancestral worldview was quickly disappearing.<ref name="ReferenceA">[[Xavier Romero-Frias]], ''The Maldive Islanders, A Study of the Popular Culture of an Ancient Ocean Kingdom'', Barcelona 1999, {{ISBN|84-7254-801-5}}</ref>
The [[Maldives]] lie in the warm equatorial area of the Indian Ocean surrounded by very deep waters. This nation is made up exclusively of coral atolls. There are about 1,200 small flat and sandy islands, but only about 200 of them are inhabited.
The Maldives have been continuously populated for millennia; therefore the folklore of these islands is very ancient.
==Myths of origin== The main myths of origin are reflecting the dependence of the Maldivians on the [[coconut]] tree and the [[tuna]] fish.
A legend says that the first inhabitants of the Maldives died in great numbers, but a great sorcerer or ''fanḍita'' man made [[coconut tree]]s grow out of the skulls of the buried corpses of the first settlers. Therefore, the coconut tree is said to have an anthropomorphic origin according to Maldive lore.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
The coconut tree occupies a central place in the present-day [[Emblem of Maldives|Maldive national emblem]].
The [[skipjack tuna|tuna fish]] is said to have been brought to the Maldivian waters by a mythical seafarer (''maalimi'') called Bodu Niyami Kalēfanu who went close to the Dagas (the mythical tree at the end of the world) to bring this valuable fish.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Myths of extinction== These myths tell that the end of the Maldives will be a great catastrophe where the islands will be submerged by the surrounding ocean. Similar myths are found in the [[Andaman Islands]] as well as in the [[Nicobar Islands]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==The origin of Malé== The first settlers in the Maldive Islands were [[Dravidian peoples|Dravidian]] people from the nearest coasts, which are in the Indian Subcontinent and coastal Ceylon. The people of [[Giraavaru (Kaafu Atoll)|Giraavaru]], an island located in [[Malé Atoll]] (now a tourist resort, after its inhabitants were removed) considered the first settlers, claim ancestry from the [[Ancient Tamil country|ancient]] [[Tamil people]].
It is said that Giraavaru fishermen used to go regularly to a certain large sandbank (''finolhu'') at the southern end of their atoll to clean tuna fish after a good catch. Owing to the large amount of tuna fish offal and blood, the waters around that sandbank looked like a big pool of blood (''maa ley gande''h). "Maa" (from the Sanskrit "Maha"), meaning big, and "Lē" meaning blood. Traditionally the first inhabitants of the Maldives, which include the Giraavaru people, didn't have kings. They lived in a simple society and were ruled by local headmen.
One day a prince from the Subcontinent called Koimala arrived to Malé Atoll sailing from the north on a big ship. The people of Giraavaru spotted his vessel from afar and welcomed him. They allowed Prince Koimala to settle on that large sandbank in the midst of the waters tainted with fishblood. Trees were planted on the sandbank and it is said that the first tree that grew on it was the papaya tree. As time went by the local islanders accepted the rule of this Northern Prince. A palace was built and the island was formally named Maa-le [[Malé]], while the nearest island was named Hulhu-le ([[Hulhulé]]).<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Evil spirits== [[File:Be-holhudu1.jpg|thumb|right|''Be''. Popular celebration in [[Holhudu]] Island. Men dressed like evil spirits walk around the island scaring the children. ]] [[File:Be-holhudu2.jpg|thumb|left|''Be''. Popular celebration in [[Holhudu]] Island. Men dressed like evil spirits beat empty ''bandiyaa'' water pots in the night.]] Most of the popular tales in Maldives are about evil spirits and their interaction with the islanders. These stories contain always a lesson in some form or the other. Certain actions became necessary in order to avoid trouble with the spirit world. These patterns of behaviour, like the importance of keeping a secret, as well as the avoidance of certain areas of the island and of inauspicious times, were an essential component of the ancient popular spirituality.<ref name="NIAS Press">Romero-Frias, Xavier (2012) ''Folk tales of the Maldives'', [http://www.niaspress.dk/catalogue2011/Catalogue_2012.pdf NIAS Press], {{ISBN|978-87-7694-104-8}}, {{ISBN|978-87-7694-105-5}}</ref>
The Maldivian spirits can take human form, even if it is not known whether they have a human origin or not. While in human shape, the malevolence of those spirits is often masked by beauty and youth. Certain Maldivian evil spirits (handi) have the appearance of charming, beautiful women. These stories about female spirits have their origin in the [[Ancient Dravidian culture|Ancient Dravidian]] [[Village Goddess]] worship and they point to the ethnic origin of the Maldive people.<ref name="NIAS Press"/>
Other evil spirits which are the subject of many folk stories in the Maldives (''furēta'') are crude monsters coming from the ocean waters. The tales about sea monsters are part of the local cultural background, which is characterized by the oceanic environment in which, along the millennia, the Maldivian culture developed.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Don Hiyala and Alifulhu== Among the stories in which the spirit and sorcery theme are not essential, the most significant is perhaps '''Don Hiyalā and Alifulhu''', the story of an extraordinarily beautiful woman, or ''faiiymini'' as called by Maldivians, who gets kidnapped from her husband Alifulhu by a villainous king. The lovers reunite at the end of the story, however, their reunion is short lived as they are soon pursued by the King's henchmen. Instead of being captured by the King's men again, Dhonhiyala chooses to commit suicide, and Ali Fulhu follows suit.
==Local fauna== [[File:XRF-maakana's treachery.jpg|thumb|right|The treachery of Maakana. Illustration of a Maldivian folktale.]] Folktales where fishes, crabs and seabirds are the heroes, like the tales about Mākana, Findana, Kalhubondage Diye, Fandiyaaru Kakuni, or Don Mohonaai Miyaru, introduce us to the world of the local fauna of the Maldive Atolls, where land animals are very few. Many of these are tales for children and some are still quite popular. Although most of the stories of this type are original, a few are foreign tales or fables which have been adapted to the island context through local storytellers or by Maldivian learned men, like the late [[Muhammad Jameel Didi|Muhammad Jamil]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Mighty sorcerers== In the ancestral oral literature of Maldivians, the sorcerer, or learned man of the island who knew the magic arts. Magic or sorcery is known in Maldives as ''fanḍita''.
The Maldivian sorcerer or ''fanḍita veriyaa'' is always portrayed in the folklore of Maldivians as a hero. Only he knew how to appease the spirits that terrified the average island folk on a daily (or better nightly) basis. Some recent stories tend to cast the sorcerer in the role of a villain, but these are totally disconnected from the ancestral Maldive lore.<ref name="NIAS Press"/>
==The conversion to Islam== {{Main|History_of_the_Maldives#Introduction_of_Islam}} According to the well-known Moroccan traveler [[Ibn Batuta]], the person responsible for converting the Maldivians to Islam as a [[Sunni]] Muslim visitor named Abu al Barakat ul Barbari. He subdued [[Mariamman|Ranna Maari]], a demon coming from the sea and convinced the King to become a Muslim.<ref>Ibn Battuta, Travels in Asia and Africa 1325-1354, tr. and ed. H. A. R. Gibb (London: Broadway House, 1929)</ref>
However, the more reliable local historical chronicles, ''Raadavalhi'' and ''Taarikh'', mention that this saint was actually a Persian from the city of [[Tabriz]], called Yusuf Shamsud-din. He is also locally known as Tabrīzugefānu.<ref>[[HCP Bell]], ''The Máldive Islands. Monograph on the History, Archæology, and Epigraphy'' with W. L. De Silva, Colombo 1940</ref> The much venerated tomb of this saint now stands opposite the grounds of Hukuru Miski, in the centre of Malé, the capital.
==Local characters== Stories about local characters, like '''Rōnu Eduru''', '''Kuda Tuttu Didi''', '''Kalhukuru''' or '''Naalaafushi Fagīru''' (the poor man of [[Naalaafushi]]) give us a glimpse on the way of life in the Maldives when the archipelago was a kingdom, and Malé, the capital, was a quaint, laid back place. In those stories we learn much about the life in the court in Malé and about the mutual interaction between the Radun (the king of Maldives) and his subjects.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Modern variants== Since there are a great number of islands in the Maldives, many folkstories have different versions according to the particular island and the storyteller in question. In recent times some stories have been abridged by contemporary Maldivian writers, like [[Abdulla Sadiq]] or Ahumadu Sharīfu (Maradū) because of their extreme length.<ref name="NIAS Press"/>
Other stories ('''Karukuru''', '''Telabagudi''' and the '''Māmeli''' tales) have been sanitized, because there was much casual reference to defecation and bodily fluids, particularly in ancient folk-stories from the outer atolls, where local values found this acceptable.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==The Koimala myth== '''Koimala Siri Mahaabarana Mahaa Radun''' ([[Dhivehi language|Dhivehi]]: ކޮއިމަލާ ސިރީ މަހާބަރަނަ މަހާ ރަދުން) or '''Koimala''' ([[Dhivehi language|Dhivehi]]: ކޮއިމަލާ literally "flower lad") or '''Koimala Kalo''' ([[Dhivehi language|Dhivehi]]: ކޮއިމަލާ ކަލޯ, literally "Lord Koimala") is a myth about the first [[List of Sultans of the Maldives|king]] of all the [[Maldive Islands]]. Some versions of the Koimala myth claim that it refers to the first ruler of the Maldives after the [[conversion to Islam]], also known as ''Dharumavantha rasgefaanu'', who ruled from 1117 to 1141. It is believed that he was also the first king from the [[Lunar Dynasty|House of Theemuge]] and the Lunar Dynasty. By other accounts he was the fourth king of the Lunar Dynastry founded by King Balaadeettiya as the Soma Vansa Kingdom; although until Koimala the house only ruled over part of the Maldives.
However, ascribing the legend to the first Islamic ruler does not explain who built the large [[Buddhist]] monuments that are present in many inhabited islands and that were built in the first millennium AD.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> It also leaves without explaining the existence of an ancient kingly dynasty in the Maldives already before the conversion, as the 12th century correspondence from the king to the [[Sangha (Buddhism)|Sangumanun]], or community of Buddhist monks, in Sathudhuvumati ([[Haddummati Atoll]]) via copper plates proves.<ref>H.A. Maniku & G.D. Wijayawardhana, ''Isdhoo Loamaafaanu''</ref>
According to Maldivian Folklore, Koimala was a prince from the [[Indian subcontinent]] who arrived in [[Malé Atoll]]. The people of [[Giraavaru people|Giraavaru]] spotted his vessel from afar and welcomed him. They allowed Prince Koimala to settle on that large sandbank in the midst of the waters tainted with fishblood. Trees were planted on the sandbank and it is said that the first tree that grew on it was the [[papaya]] tree. As time went by the local islanders accepted the rule of this northern prince. A palace was built and the island was formally named Maa-le ([[Malé]]), while the nearest island was named Hulhu-le ([[Hulhulé Island|Hulhulé]]). Since then Malé has been the seat of the Maldivian crown and now the head of state.
A different account claims Koimala to be a [[Sinhala people|Sinhalese]] prince of royal birth from [[Sri Lanka|Ceylon]]. The prince is said to have married the Ceylon king's daughter and made a voyage with her in two vessels from Ceylon. Reaching the Maldives they were becalmed, and rested a while at [[Rasgetheemu (Raa Atoll)|''Rasgetheemu'']] island (meaning the King's Island) in [[Northern Maalhosmadulhu Atoll]]. The Maldive Islanders who were then [[Buddhism|Buddhists]], learning that the two chief visitors were of royal descent from the Buddhist kingdom of Ceylon, invited them to remain and ultimately proclaimed Koimala their king at Rasgetheemu. The new king and his spouse migrated to Malé and settled there with the consent of the [[Indigenous peoples|aborigines]] of Giraavaru (See [[Giraavaru people]]) - then the most important community of Malé Atoll. Until then the Maldives is thought to have been ruled by different [[matriarchy|matriarchies]] in different atolls.
After the settlement in Male', two vessels were dispatched to bring more people of his race to populate Male'. It wasn't tradition for the Giraavaru and perhaps other aboriginal people of the Maldives to marry outside their community.
It is not clear, how much of this legend is true. Although he might have been the first king of the whole of Maldives, the story of a prince might actually be a corruption of the stories of King [[Soorudasaruna-Adeettiya]] and King [[Balaadeettiya]]- both exiled princes from the [[Kalinga (historical kingdom)|Kalinga]] Kingdom of India who founded the Solar and Lunar Dynastries of the Maldives. According to this source (''Kitab fi Athaari Meedoo el-Qadimiyyeh'' by Allama Ahmed Shihabuddine relating from The ''Maapanansa'' copper plates), Koimala or Siri Mahaabarana, the son of King Siri Bovana Aananda was the fourth king of the Lunar Dynastry and uncle to [[Dhovemi of the Maldives|King Dhovemi]] (Siri Bavana-adiththa) the first Sultan (Muslim king) of the Maldives.
Koimala is said to have become the King of the 14 [[atolls]] and two thousand islands of the ''Dheeva Mahal''. His kingdom was referred to as being ''Malikaddu dhemedhu''- or 'all that lies between the [[Minicoy island|Maliku]] and [[Seenu Atoll|Addu]]. He fought against the Raja Dada's (or the forces of the Tamil emperor [[Raja Raja Chola I]] of the [[Chola empire]]) Indians to claim the two northern most atolls for the newly formed Maldivian kingdom. Koimala was succeeded by his nephew [[Dhovemi of the Maldives|Dhovemi Kalaminja]] in 1141.
==Further reading== * [[Xavier Romero-Frias]], ''The Maldive Islanders, A Study of the Popular Culture of an Ancient Ocean Kingdom''. Barcelona 1999, {{ISBN|84-7254-801-5}} *Xavier Romero-Frias, ''Folk tales of the Maldives'', Nordic Institute of Asian Studies Press, Copenhagen 2012, {{ISBN|978-87-7694-104-8}}, {{ISBN|978-87-7694-105-5}} * Doń Hiyala āi Alifulu. ''Abdullah Sādigu, Mulī''. Novelty Press. Malé 1996. * ''Asian Variations in Ramayana''. Edited by K.R. Srinivasa Iyengar. Sahitya Akademi. Delhi 1983 * Furatama Satēka Raivaru. ''Divehi Bahāi Tārikhah Khidmaiykurā Qaumī Markazu''. Malé 1996. *[[Vladimir Propp]], ''Morphology of the Folktale'', Austin, Texas 1 984, {{ISBN|0-292-78376-0}} * Divehi Ādakāda. ''Bābāgē Donmaniku. Divehi Bahāi Tārikhah Khidmaiykurā Qaumī Markazu''. Malé 1993 * Dońkamanā. ''Ābāru''. Malé 1974.
